attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Tier 2 Capital.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The most sophisticated of the three Basel II approaches available for operational risk. Under AMA, the institutions internal operational risk models will generate the regulatory capital requirements. These models will need to meet set quantitative and qualitative criteria.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Those resources that a financial institution holds on its balance sheet above the level necessary to carry on its current operations. These reserves are held against uncertainty and also to take advantage of future opportunities.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development group of 30 member countries. Capital adequacy requirements distinguish between exposures in OECD and non-OECD sovereigns and banks.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Credit Conversion Factor.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Internal estimates are those parameters for use in models that have been generated by using the banks own loss experiences. These estimates are normally subject to some qualitative criteria.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The committee of the Bank of England that is responsible for macroprudential oversight of the financial services system as a whole.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Committee of European Banking Supervisors.

Resource.label: Committee of European Banking Supervisors
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Committee of European Banking Supervisors

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The Originate-to-distribute model of lending, where the originator of a loan sells it to various third parties.

Resource.label: Standardised Approach to Market Risk
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Standardised Approach to Market Risk

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The most basic approach available for the Basel II calculation of capital requirements for market risk. This approach is based on a more formulaic approach with supervisory determined parameters. These requirements are mostly unchanged from those adopted in the 1996 Market risk amendment to the Basel Accord (Basel I).

Resource.label: Value at Risk model
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Value at Risk model

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A statistical technique designed to give an estimate of the maximum loss that could be made for a given factor of confidence over a set time horizon under normal market conditions.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The underlying services and products that a bank or investment firm offers to the economy.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The substantial revision of the previous Basel I and Basel II accords published in December 2010 following endorsement by the G20 Leaders at the Seoul summit in November 2010.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Expected loss. A term to describe PD*EAD*LGD.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A principle of the (Basel II) IRB framework which requires banks to seek out and take into account as much information as possible in order to accurately assess the risk of borrowers and transactions.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Capital charge introduced in Basel III to cover the risk of mark-to-market losses on the expected counterparty risk to OTC derivatives.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The nature and extent of the significant risks that a firm it is prepared to accept in meeting its business objectives and regulatory obligations.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Capital requirements tend to fluctuate with the business economic cycle, rising in a downturn. This increase leads to a further restricting of credit which in turn leads to still higher capital requirements, creating a self reinforcing economic behaviour known as pro-cyclicality.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The risk of losses of on- and off-balance sheet positions arising from changes in market price.

Resource.label: Market risk
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Standardised Approach to Market Risk

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The exchange of principal and interest in one currency for the same in another currency.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A firm's recovery plan that sets out credible options to recover financial strength and viability should the firm come under severe stress from a range of scenarios, including both idiosyncratic and market-wide stress.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The exercise of caution or prudential measures pertaining to an individual bank or institution.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Many repos are overnight transactions, with the sale taking place one day and being reversed the next day. Long-term repos can extend for a month or more.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Under (Basel II) IMM banks that meet qualifying supervisory standards are permitted to use their 'own estimates' developed through internal models for calculating counterparty credit risk exposure. IMM is applicable to both OTC derivatives and SFTs.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Standardised Approach to Operational Risk

Resource.label: Standardised Approach to Operational Risk
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Standardised Approach to Operational Risk

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The name used to describe the 2004 Basel Accord.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The process by which a bank ensures that an IRB or similar system is producing accurate and consistent results in line with its underlying objectives and regulatory requirements.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Interest rate risk is the exposure of a bank's financial condition to adverse movements in interest rates. Accepting this risk is a normal part of banking and can be an important source of profitability and shareholder value.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A risk-weighted asset (RWA) reflects the amount of a bank's asset (e.g. a lending exposure), adjusted for risk (e.g. risk of credit default). A risk-weighting reflects the degree of risk and is multiplied by the value of the asset to determine its RWA value.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The amendment of the Consolidated Banking Directive (2000/12/EC) and the Capital Adequacy Directive (93/6/EEC), under which the second Basel Accord (Basel II) was implemented in the EU.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Standardised Approach to Credit Risk.

Resource.label: Standardised Approach to Credit Risk
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Standardised Approach to Credit Risk

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: An agreement by a third party to cover the potential loss to a credit institution should a specified counterparty default on their commitments.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Credit Default Swap.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Loan to Value.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Interest Rate Risk in the Banking Book.

Resource.label: High volatility commercial real estate
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\High volatility commercial real estate

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Significant concentrations in certain property (normally commercial) acquisitions, development and construction loans that lack 'substantial equity' or are not 'significantly pre-leased'. For instance lending where the performance of the lending will very much depend on the success of the underlying investment.

Resource.label: Abbreviation
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\High volatility commercial real estate\Attribute0

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Loss Given Default.

Resource.label: LGD
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Advanced Internal Ratings Based Approach

Resource.label: LGD
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Foundation Internal Ratings Based Approach

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Reflects the amount that would be lost should a counterparty default. (Usually expressed as a percentage).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The processes by which an institution manages its various sources of risk. These include internal controls and procedures, tools to reduce or mitigate risks and the policies a bank adopts to reduce potential risk exposures.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Statutory power of a resolution authority to restructure the liabilities of a distressed financial institution by writing down its unsecured debt and/or converting it to equity, to achieve prompt recapitalisation and restructuring.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Something that is expressed as a numeric measure i.e. an amount, ratio or percentage.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Current Exposure Method.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Recovery and Resolution Plan.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Fixed Overhead Requirement. Capital requirement for a regulated UK investment firm that is equal to 25% of the firms 'relevant' fixed expenditure i.e. total expenditure in the firm's accounts but excluding certain operating expenses such as staff bonuses, interest payments and transaction commissions and fees.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Adverse financial market conditions, including disruption in financial markets, generally affecting firms operating within the firm's own market sector.

Resource.label: Basel Committee on Banking Supervision
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Basel Committee on Banking Supervision

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The BIS committee established by the G-10 in 1974, with representation from individual countries' central banks and supervisory authorities, which formulates international supervisory standards and guidelines.

Resource.label: Basel Committee on Banking Supervision
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Bank for International Settlements

Resource.label: Abbreviation
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Basel Committee on Banking Supervision\Attribute0

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: That pertaining to the quality or nature of something, which is expressed descriptively.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: International body established in 2009 to develop and promote financial regulatory policies, coordinating the work of national authorities and other international standards bodies.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Contingency Funding Plan.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The supervisor for the country in which a foreign bank has a banking office or subsidiary.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Recovery and Resolution Directive.

Resource.label: Recovery and Resolution Directive
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Recovery and Resolution Directive

Resource.label: Internal Rating Based Approach
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Internal Rating Based Approach

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Approach to credit risk under which a bank may use internal estimates to generate risk components for use in their Basel II credit risk capital assessment. There are two approaches: Foundation (FIRB) and Advanced (AIRB).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The minimum amount of regulatory capital that a financial institution must hold to meet its Pillar 1 requirements for credit, market and operational risk.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Extent to which individual items in a group display the same risk characteristics e.g. assets in a pool.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Assets not pledged (either explicitly or implicitly) to secure, collateralise or credit enhance any transaction. For regulatory purposes, assets received in reverse repo transactions that have not been rehypothecated (and legally available for the bank's use) are considered 'unencumbered'.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The exchange of one security for another, most commonly a currency swap or an interest rate swap.

Resource.label: Standardised Approach to Operational Risk
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Standardised Approach to Operational Risk

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The intermediate of the three approaches to operational risk under Basel II. Capital requirements are calculated by taking a three-year average of gross income for eight defined business lines. Each of these eight income measures are then multiplied by a given risk weight (between 12 and 18 per cent) and then summed together to arrive at an overall capital requirement.

Resource.label: Abbreviation
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Standardised Approach to Operational Risk\Attribute0

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The exercise of caution or prudential measures pertaining to the wider financial system and economy.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The most simplistic of the three Basel II approaches to the measurement of operational risk. Under this method a bank calculates its operational risk regulatory capital requirements by taking a single risk-weighted (15 percent for the majority of banks and 12 per cent for banks operating on a limited license) multiple of a three-year average of gross income to produce their regulatory capital requirements.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The risk that a counterparty to a transaction will fail to fulfil their contractual obligations. Counterparty risk is greatest in contracts drawn up directly between two parties and least in contracts where an intermediary acts as the central counterparty.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A plan of contingency measures for managing and preserving liquidity in various adverse situations.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Forms of lending that are unsecured, revolve (i.e. they do not represent a fixed amount for a fixed time, can be added to and reduced), and are uncommitted (i.e. able to be withdrawn at any time). An example would be a credit card or an overdraft facility.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The 1988 Basel Accord setting out the initial framework for the assessment of regulatory capital requirements for credit risk. Subsequently amended in 1996 to add capital requirements for market risk.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Individual Capital Guidance.

Resource.label: ICG
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Supervisory Review and Evaluation Process

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Repurchase agreement. An agreement whereby one party sells the other a security at a specified price with a commitment to buy the security back at a later date for another specified price. Most repos are overnight transactions, with the sale taking place one day and being reversed the next day. Long-term repos (or term repos) can extend for a month or more.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Supervisory Review and Evaluation Process.

Resource.label: Supervisory Review and Evaluation Process
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Supervisory Review and Evaluation Process

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The assessment and reporting of capital adequacy for a firm and its subsidiaries on a consolidated basis, treating the group as a single entity. In order to solo consolidate, the bank must have significant management control of the subsidiary.

Resource.label: Individual Liquidity Adequacy Assessment
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Individual Liquidity Adequacy Assessment

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A firm's assessment the type and quality of liquidity resources it thinks it should hold against the sources of liquidity risk.

Resource.label: Abbreviation
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Individual Liquidity Adequacy Assessment\Attribute0

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A financial group with cross-sector activities. For instance a financial conglomerate may contain a combination of credit institutions, investment firms and insurance operations.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Techniques to reduce the credit risks to which a financial institution is exposed. Exposures may be collateralised, they may be guaranteed by a third party, or an institution may purchase a credit derivative to offset various forms of credit risk. Additionally they may agree to net loans owed to them against deposits from the same counterparty.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Foundation Internal Ratings Based Approach.

Resource.label: Foundation Internal Ratings Based Approach
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Foundation Internal Ratings Based Approach

Resource.label: FIRB
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Internal Rating Based Approach

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Loans and other commercial activities that are made to a country's central government or its departments and agencies.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Guidance given by the supervisor (FCA/PRA) on the amount and quality of capital resources which the FCA/PRA considers that a firm needs to hold. Firms are expected to maintain financial resources at or above the level specified in the ICG at all times.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The Act of Parliament that creates the new regulatory framework consisting of the Financial Policy Committee, the Prudential Regulation Authority and the Financial Conduct Authority, replacing the Financial Services Authority from 1 April 2013.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: An add-on to capital requirements, as proposed under Basel III, to be deployed by regulators during a period of excessive credit growth to protect against future losses.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Exposures arising through the issuing of credit to individuals, corporate entities, other non-corporate bodies, governments and countries.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The amount of uncertainty or risk about the size of changes in the value or measure of an asset or liability. For example, provisions for loan defaults may assume average expected losses. The potential for eventual losses, and therefore provisions, to vary from this expectation is a source of volatility risk.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The European Banking Authority (EBA) provides advice to the European Commission and other EU institutions on banking regulation and policy issues. The EBA replaced the Committee of European Banking Supervisors (CEBS) in January 2011. It is responsible for promoting the convergence of supervisory practice throughout the European Union. The EBA also fosters common implementation and consistent application of Community legislation.

Resource.label: European Banking Authority
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Committee of European Banking Supervisors

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The use of pledged assets, such as collateral held against client lending, for a firm's own purposes. This allows an investment bank to use collateral posted by its clients as collateral for its own activities.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The Capital Charge for Operational Risk i.e. the amount of regulatory capital that must be assigned for operational risk.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Any public sector entity, including regional governments, councils and local authorities that have independent revenue raising powers.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive.

Resource.label: Recovery and Resolution Directive
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Recovery and Resolution Directive

Resource.label: Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Overnight Index Swap. An interest rate swap that exchanges a fixed rate of interest for floating rate payments based on a notional principal. The floating rate is a specified published daily overnight rate for the OIS currency.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Central Counterparty.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Reverse Stress Testing.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The date on which payment of a financial obligation is due.

Resource.label: Maturity
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Advanced Internal Ratings Based Approach

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Individual Liquidity Systems Assessment.

Resource.label: Individual Liquidity Systems Assessment
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Individual Liquidity Systems Assessment

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Where a bank has committed to the sale of equity or other security, but the payment and delivery has not yet been settled.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Liquidity Coverage Ratio.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: In the context of the Net Stable Funding Ratio, it is the total amount of a bank's (1) capital, (2) preferred stock with maturity of equal to or greater than one year, (3) liabilities with effective maturities of one year or greater and (4) that portion of 'stable' non-maturity deposits and/or term deposits with maturities of less than one year that would be expected to stay with the bank for an extended period in a firm-specific (idiosyncratic) stress event.

Resource.label: Available Stable Funding
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Net Stable Funding Ratio

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The commercial operations and management of banks which create the possibility of potential financial loss.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Internal Ratings Based approach.

Resource.label: IRB
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Internal Rating Based Approach

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: An amount of a firm's capital that is held to absorb possible future losses and/or meet higher capital requirements in adverse circumstances, such as an economic downturn. The amount is based on the result of the firm's stress test.

Resource.label: Internal models or processes
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Internal models or processes

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The firm's process for generating estimates of risk components for use in the calculation of regulatory or economic capital requirements. These models are usually computer simulations that use past data or equivalent cohorts as a guide to estimating the characteristics of a type of risk. For instance, past data on mortgage defaults may be used to generate the probability of default of a new mortgage borrower.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The sufficiency of a bank's capital to meet its business requirements and regulatory obligations.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Maximum. On a sliding scale, the ceiling would be the maximum percentage or amount that would apply.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Property is used for domestic occupation rather than commercial purposes. This would represent housing stock purchased for self occupancy or for residential letting.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A form of capital raising instrument issued by a financial institution that is secured on a given portfolio of mortgages on its balance sheet. Should the bank be wound up the bondholders would have claim on these assets in preference to other creditors.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Guidance given by the PRA on (i) the amount and makeup of liquidity resources that a firm needs to hold and (ii) what the PRA considers to be an appropriate funding profile for the firm.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: An undertaking that receives deposits or other repayable funds from the public and grants credits from its own accounts i.e. a bank or savings bank (from the Banking Consolidation Directive).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The analysis of possible alternative future events and the possible outcomes that may arise from them, often as a prelude to stress testing to determine the impact on a firm's capital, liquidity and profitability.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The probability that a counterparty will fail to meet their obligations under a contractual agreement.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Credit Support Annex.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The Prudential Sourcebook for banks, building societies and investment firms.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Available Stable Funding.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Techniques and financial instruments designed to reduce a bank's exposure to risks. These may include insurance against operational risks and the use of internal limits, credit risk mitigation, netting agreements, hedging instruments etc.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The difference between the total value of a business and the value of the net assets on its balance sheet. The value represents the ability of the business to generate profits and cash in the future.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A liquidity metric representing the proportion of total funding that is deemed as stable (or core) funding. See also Turner Ratio.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The requirements under Pillar 3 for a financial institution / group to disclose information demonstrating how they meet their capital requirements.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: An agreement to buy (sell) an amount of currency at an agreed rate and to resell (repurchase) the same amount of currency for a later date to (from) the same counterparty, also at an agreed rate. Not to be confused with a cross currency swap.

Resource.label: Supervisory Review and Evaluation Process
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Supervisory Review and Evaluation Process

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The process under which the supervisor (FCA/PRA) reviews and evaluates a firm's ICAAP and determines its ICG, at the same time identifying any weaknesses or inadequacies and takinge prudential measures and other supervisory actions, if necessary.

Resource.label: Abbreviation
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Supervisory Review and Evaluation Process\Attribute0

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Exposure at Default

Resource.label: EAD
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Advanced Internal Ratings Based Approach

Resource.label: EAD
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Foundation Internal Ratings Based Approach

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Over-the-counter (off-exchange trading).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Net Stable Funding Ratio.

Resource.label: Net Stable Funding Ratio
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Net Stable Funding Ratio

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The valuation of an asset or liability based on its current market price, or that of similar assets or liabilities.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Minimum requirements that firms must meet at all times in order to be permitted to carry on the regulated activities in which they engage. Firms will need to meet both FCA-specific and PRA-specific Threshold Conditions under the new UK regulatory framework.

Resource.label: Net Stable Funding Ratio
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Net Stable Funding Ratio

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The ratio of the amount of Available Stable Funding to the required amount of stable funding, which must be greater than 100% to meet the minimum Basel III regulatory standard.

Resource.label: Abbreviation
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Net Stable Funding Ratio\Attribute0

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A trading book consists of positions in financial instruments and commodities held either with intent to trade, or in order to hedge other elements of the trading book. To be eligible for trading book capital treatment, financial instruments must either be free of any restrictive covenants on their tradability, or able to be hedged completely. In addition, positions should be frequently and accurately valued, and a portfolio should be actively managed.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Credit Risk Mitigation

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The new regulatory authority, a subsidiary of the Bank of England, that took over responsibility for the prudential regulation of UK banks from the FSA on 1 April 2013.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Required Stable Funding. See Net Stable Funding Ratio.

Resource.label: Net Stable Funding Ratio
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Net Stable Funding Ratio

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The Basel I method for banks to estimate their exposure to counterparty credit risk for derivatives. The maximum potential increase in value before maturity is added to the market value of the derivative (or its replacement cost in the event of default). The result is then adjusted for the value of collateral and multiplied by the risk weight of the counterparty.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Through the Cycle. The recurring and fluctuating levels of economic activity experienced over a long period of time. In the context of an internal ratings system, an approach that leaves a borrower's rating unchanged over the course of the credit business cycle, but that expects default levels for each grade to vary with the cycle.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Securities financing transaction.

Resource.label: Individual Liquidity Systems Assessment
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Individual Liquidity Systems Assessment

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A firm's assessment of its compliance with ILAS systems and controls requirements.

Resource.label: Abbreviation
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Individual Liquidity Systems Assessment\Attribute0

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A regulatory intervention framework designed to ensure that the PRA identifies and responds to emerging risks at an early stage. As the PRA determines that a firm's viability has deteriorated, the firm will be moved to a higher PIF stage and supervisory action will be taken accordingly.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Countercyclical Capital Buffer.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Reduction in a bank's deposit base, or loan portfolio, as customer deposits are withdrawn, or customer loans are paid off, and not replaced at the same rate.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A firm-specific stress scenario where the market and/or customers perceive that the particular firm is in difficulties, leading to a loss of confidence in the firm's ability to continue business as usual.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Prudential Sourcebook.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Probability of Default.

Resource.label: PD
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Advanced Internal Ratings Based Approach

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Quantitative Impact Study. For example, as carried out by regulators to gauge the impact of new proposals on banks affected.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Prudential Regulation Authority.

Resource.label: PRA
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Supervisory Review and Evaluation Process

Resource.label: PRA
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Individual Liquidity Adequacy Standards

Resource.label: PRA
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Supervisory Liquidity Review Process

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Small or medium-sized enterprise.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A Credit Support Annex agreement under which only one of the counterparties is required to post collateral.

Resource.label: Systemically Important Financial Institution
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Systemically Important Financial Institution

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Financial institution whose distress or disorderly failure, because of its size, complexity and systemic inter-connectedness, would cause significant disruption to the wider financial system and economy.

Resource.label: Abbreviation
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Systemically Important Financial Institution\Attribute0

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Alternative Standardised Approach

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The amount of capital a bank needs to cover all the risks it faces. This would be a combination of the requirements for credit, market and operational risk and any additional capital required for risks captured under Pillar 2.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A financial institution that acts as an intermediary between market participants, such as a clearinghouse that guarantees the performance of the trading contract. This reduces the amount of counterparty risk that market participants are exposed to.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Proactive Intervention Framework.

Resource.label: Internal Capital Adequacy Assessment Process
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Internal Capital Adequacy Assessment Process

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Assessment process (or report of assessment) under which a bank considers whether it has adequate capital to meet both its business requirements and regulatory obligations.

Resource.label: Abbreviation
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Internal Capital Adequacy Assessment Process\Attribute0

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Defined Liquidity Group.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Capital Requirements Directive.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Also called Tier 1 capital. The equity (share capital) and retained earnings of a financial institution.

Resource.label: Committee of European Banking Supervisors
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Committee of European Banking Supervisors

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Former advisor to the European Commission on banking regulation replaced by the European Banking Authority (EBA) in January 2011.

Resource.label: Abbreviation
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Committee of European Banking Supervisors\Attribute0

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Systemically Important Financial Institution.

Resource.label: Systemically Important Financial Institution
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Systemically Important Financial Institution

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Individual Capital Assessment.

Resource.label: ICA
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Supervisory Review and Evaluation Process

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: FCA's regulatory approach based on three 'pillars': preventative work through continuous assessment of firms; event-driven work to be responsive to emerging problems; and sector-driven work to address cross-firm and product issues where consumers are at risk.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Systemically Important Financial Institution.

Resource.label: Systemically Important Financial Institution
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Systemically Important Financial Institution

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Capital Planning Buffer.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The European Council is formed of representatives of Member States governments (usually Ministers) who meet to discuss issues of importance and agree legislative proposals. For Financial Services the main Council is ECOFIN (Economic and Financial Affairs committee) at which the Chancellor represents the UK.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Long-term Repo.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Liquidity risk profile.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: These include audits or other appropriate oversight mechanisms to ensure the integrity of the information used by senior officials in overseeing compliance with policies and limits.

Resource.label: Individual Liquidity Adequacy Standards
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Individual Liquidity Adequacy Standards

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The rules under which the adequacy of a firm's liquidity resources must be assessed, both by the firm and by the PRA.

Resource.label: Abbreviation
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Individual Liquidity Adequacy Standards\Attribute0

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A Limited Licence Firm that can hold client money or securities (and is not a UCITS investment firm). Base (minimum) capital requirements of EURO 125,000 apply.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The pledging of securities or other assets as collateral to secure a loan or credit facility.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: European Banking Authority.

Resource.label: EBA
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Committee of European Banking Supervisors

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Loans and other commercial lending made to individuals or small businesses (rather than large companies or institutions).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A firm responsible for dealing, arranging and managing qualifying investment items as defined within the scope of the Investment Services Directive.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Capital Resources Requirement.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Risk Asset Ratio

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Bank for International Settlements.

Resource.label: Bank for International Settlements
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Bank for International Settlements

Resource.label: BIS
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Basel Committee on Banking Supervision

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Export Credit Agency

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The exercise of caution e.g. Prudential Regulations are those which legislate capital and liquidity adequacy and other measures of restraint.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A Core Funding Ratio that represents the total of retail deposits plus long-term wholesale funding (over 1 year) as a proportion of total liabilities.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Capital Adequacy Directive.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Products such as futures, options and swaps, which derive their values from the movement in price of the underlying bank assets on which they are secured.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Wrong-way risk.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Financial Conduct Authority.

Resource.label: FCA
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Supervisory Review and Evaluation Process

Resource.label: Independent Commission on Banking
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Independent Commission on Banking

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Established by the UK Government in June 2010 to consider reforms to the UK banking sector to promote financial stability and competition. The Commission, chaired by Sir John Vickers, produced its report and recommendations in September 2011.

Resource.label: Abbreviation
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Independent Commission on Banking\Attribute0

Resource.label: Recovery and Resolution Directive
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Recovery and Resolution Directive

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The framework for the recovery and resolution of banks and investment firms as proposed by the European Commission in June 2012.

Resource.label: Abbreviation
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Recovery and Resolution Directive\Attribute0

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The part of the Basel II Accord that sets out the disclosure requirements for banks to publish certain details of their risks, capital and risk management, with the aim of strengthening market discipline.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: An agreement under which the buyer of the CDS receives a payment should a credit obligation fail, effectively insuring against credit default.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The weighting applied to off-balance sheet items to determine their exposure value (based on the type of exposure) under the Standardised Approach to credit risk, before applying credit risk weightings.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Independent Commission on Banking.

Resource.label: Independent Commission on Banking
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Independent Commission on Banking

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The set of components that support and sustain risk management throughout the organisation.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Risk-weighted asset.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Point-in-Time - an internal rating system that assesses a counterparty's condition over the course of a specified time horizon, typically its probability of defaulting within one year.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Commonly used in regulatory terminology to mean a bank (credit Institution) or an investment firm.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Undertaking for Collective Investments in Transferable Securities. UCITS are collective funds which can be sold across national borders within the EU in accordance with the UCITS Directive.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Advanced Measurement Approach.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Standardised Approach to Operational Risk

Resource.label: Standardised Approach to Operational Risk
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Standardised Approach to Operational Risk

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Off-balance sheet.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: High volatility commercial real estate

Resource.label: High volatility commercial real estate
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\High volatility commercial real estate

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Areas where a supervisory authority sets lower standards than those required by the revised Accord and/or Capital Requirements Directive.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The amount of regulatory capital resources that a firm must hold. Synonym for Capital Resources Requirement.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The risk that a borrower (counterparty) will not repay a loan.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Financial firms that are parents or subsidiaries within the same group and have one or more exposures to each other.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: See also Minimum Capital Requirements. The part of the Basel II Accord that sets out the calculations of regulatory capital requirements for credit, market and operational risk.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Credit Risk Capital Requirement. The capital charge (or capital resources requirement) for credit risk.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Indicators or forecasts of the potential for credit loss because of an obligor's failure to pay, a delay in payment, or partial repayment.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Asset-backed commercial paper.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A variant to the Standardised Approach to calculating operational risk Pillar 1 capital requirements for retail and commercial banking business lines.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A transaction for which the borrower provides assets (physical or financial) as security against a loan. The assets would become the property of the lender should the borrower fail to repay the loan; for example a mortgage, in which the property is the collateral.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Advanced Internal Ratings Based Approach.

Resource.label: Advanced Internal Ratings Based Approach
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Advanced Internal Ratings Based Approach

Resource.label: AIRB
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Internal Rating Based Approach

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Internal Model Method.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Borrower or borrowing group to whom a loan is extended.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A BIPRU investment firm that is not a BIPRU 50K firm, nor a BIPRU 125K firm, nor a UCITS investment firm). Base (minimum) capital requirements of EURO 730,000 apply.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Basic Indicator Approach

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A plan prepared by the authorities (Bank of England and PRA) for putting a firm that fails to meet threshold conditions into resolution in an orderly manner and with minimal impact on the financial system.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The Group of Central Bank Governors and Heads of Supervision, the Basel Committee's oversight body.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: In contrast to other stress testing, reverse stress testing starts from assuming an adverse outcome, such as failure of the business, and attempts to determine the possible chain of events, and their degree of severity, under which this may occur.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Capital required to meet the needs of a firm's business activities.

Resource.label: Foundation Internal Ratings Based Approach
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Foundation Internal Ratings Based Approach

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The intermediate of the three Basel II approaches to credit risk. Banks are required to use internal models to calculate their regulatory capital requirements. The supervisory authority will supply some of the parameters for these models (LGDs and EADs).

Resource.label: Abbreviation
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Foundation Internal Ratings Based Approach\Attribute0

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Global Systemically Important Bank. See also Systemically Important Financial Institution.

Resource.label: Systemically Important Financial Institution
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Systemically Important Financial Institution

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: An assessment of a company's credit worthiness produced by an agency. These ratings are produced for a company on a fee-based basis.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A group of entities that a firm's regulatory supervisor has agreed may be relied upon for liquidity support or that rely upon the firm for liquidity support.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Residential mortgage backed securities.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Core Funding Ratio.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The risks associated with the internal failure of systems or people, or the risk arising from external events. These are risk events such as internal fraud, the failure of internal IT infrastructure (e.g. for payment and settlement) or external factors such as terrorism, which have the potential to impact on the institutions ability to carry out its business.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The company with ultimate control over the subsidiaries and sub groups within a financial group.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The ratio (percentage) of the value of a loan to the value of the security taken against it; usually used in relation to mortgages.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Individual Liquidity Guidance.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: External credit assessment institution (rating agency) that is recognised by the regulator for risk weighting purposes under the Basel II Standardised Approach to Credit Risk and for securitisation-based approaches.

Resource.label: Standardised Approach to Credit Risk
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Standardised Approach to Credit Risk

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Common Equity Tier 1 Capital. This is mostly restricted to share capital, share premium, retained earnings and regulatory adjustments (deductions).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The process under which an institution identifies the risks to which it is exposed either through its commercial activities, or through its own internal business processes.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The trading of financial instruments (such as stocks, bonds, commodities or derivatives) directly between two parties, rather than via a trading exchange such as a futures exchange or stock exchange.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Funds transfer pricing. FTP is an internal measurement framework designed to assess the financial impact of a bank's sources and uses of funds. FTP measures the 'true' cost of funding an earning asset and credit for an interest-bearing liability. Transfer pricing rates vary according to repricing term and other attributes, with the aim to represent the alternative 'opportunity' rate for the bank's sources or uses of funds.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A financial institution's internal process/strategy for handling the risk inherent in their operations. This will also include how management are involved in the monitoring of these risks and what systems the organisation has to reduce the probability or severity of risk events.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A report by a 'Skilled Person' appointed by the FCA, PRA or Bank of England to address a particular regulatory need identified by the supervisor relating to a regulated financial services business under Section 166 of the (amended) Financial Services and Markets Act 2000.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The highest quality form of a bank's capital. It is composed of core capital, which consists primarily of common stock and disclosed reserves (or retained earnings), perpetual non-cumulative preference shares and innovative tier one capital. Under Basel III, innovative hybrid capital instruments with step-up clauses are being phased out.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: International Swaps and Derivatives Association.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The result of initiatives by banks to combine the results of their internal experience of losses, usually where only limited data is available to individual banks.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: These are liabilities where the company is uncertain as to the amount, or timing of the expected future costs.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Financial Policy Committee.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Counterparty credit risk.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The expected exposure of a bank for a given loan upon default of the counterparty.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Public Sector Entity.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Calculation of capital requirements for a consolidated sub-group within a larger group.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: London Investment Banking Association.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Basel Committee on Banking Supervision.

Resource.label: Basel Committee on Banking Supervision
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Basel Committee on Banking Supervision

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Credit Valuation Adjustment.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The new regulatory authority focussing on consumer protection and markets. The FCA has, inter alia, taken over responsibility from the FSA for supervising conduct of business as well as prudential regulation of those firms not shared with the Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA).

Resource.label: Supervisory Liquidity Review Process
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Supervisory Liquidity Review Process

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The process under which the adequacy of a firm's liquidity resources and ILAA is assessed by the PRA.

Resource.label: Abbreviation
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Supervisory Liquidity Review Process\Attribute0

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: An annex to the master agreement between two parties that trade over-the-counter derivatives, which documents the rules governing the mutual posting of collateral (that provides credit protection).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Value at Risk.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The risk that arises when the exposure at default is positively (adversely) correlated to the probability of default (or credit quality of the counterparty). Put another way, when default risk and credit exposure increase together.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: An institution responsible for financing arrangement allowing a foreign buyer of exported goods and/or services to defer payment over a period of time, often providing an insurance or guarantee arrangement.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The failure by a party to fulfil their obligations on a loan repayment, future or options contract when they fall due. For regulatory purposes, default may be deemed to occur if the obligor is unlikely to pay or repayment is more than a specified number of days overdue.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A direction waiving or modifying a rule set by the supervisory authority.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The reduction in the value of an asset in determining its market value for meeting regulatory requirements, its worth as collateral or its disposal value under adverse sale conditions.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The General Prudential Sourcebook for banks, building societies, insurers and investment firms.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Simulation analysis in which one or more key quantitative assumptions are changed to assess their effect on the final outcome. In comparison, stress testing considers whole scenarios that draw on numerous qualitative assumptions to determine the overall potential impact.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Disclosure requirements.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Liquidity monitoring tool provided by the PRA for banks to monitor their ILG as well as a range of other liquidity metrics.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A BIPRU investment firm that is not authorised to deal on its own account in financial instruments on a firm commitment basis.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Market Risk Capital Requirement. The capital charge (or capital resources requirement) for market risk.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A process by which banks adjust the delinquency status of loans based on subsequent good performance, even though not all arrears under the original repayment schedule have been paid off.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The risk assessment framework that was used by the FSA prior to being replaced by the FCA's Firm Systematic Framework designed to meet conduct objectives and the PRA's Proactive Intervention Framework focused on meeting prudential objectives.

Resource.label: Standardised Approach to Credit Risk
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Standardised Approach to Credit Risk

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The most basic approach to credit risk under Basel II. This approach is similar to Basel I requirements, with regulatory capital requirements calculated by multiplying the value of a bank's exposure by an appropriate risk weight. The risk weights under the revised standardised approach are calculated by using external credit ratings that map onto defined credit steps.

Resource.label: Abbreviation
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Standardised Approach to Credit Risk\Attribute0

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Liquidity risk management.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Liquidity contingency plan.

Resource.label: Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: EU framework for recovery and resolution of banks and investment firms, which aims to provide authorities with tools to act sufficiently early to minimise the impact of a bank's failure on the economy and financial system.

Resource.label: Abbreviation
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive\Attribute0

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A BIPRU investment firm that is authorised to deal on its own account but only to fulfil client orders.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The authority responsible for regulatory supervision of the finance and banking sector.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Integrated Group

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The part of the PRA's Handbook that sets out detailed prudential requirements for the banks that they regulate.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The requirement for a bank to ensure that a risk assessment process or risk measurement approach is widely used, firmly embedded and integrated in its business, and not merely adopted to satisfy particular regulatory demands.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Self-imposed parameters designed to set boundaries for the levels of risks or exposure permitted. For instance a bank may limit the value of the amount of exposure it is allowed to have to some business lines.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The requirement to calculate capital requirements for an entire financial group rather than for an individual bank. This process is to ensure that the group as a whole has capital adequate to cover the risks in its regulated and unregulated entities.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: An agreement to net gains and losses on transactions so that a single net amount is owed by one party to the other.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Items that appear within the bank's balance sheet e.g. loans which have actually been made (see off balance sheet, above).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Internal Capital Adequacy Assessment Process.

Resource.label: ICAAP
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Supervisory Review and Evaluation Process

Resource.label: Internal Capital Adequacy Assessment Process
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Internal Capital Adequacy Assessment Process

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: London Interbank Offered Rate. A daily published rate based on the interest rates at which banks borrow unsecured funds from other banks in the London wholesale money market (interbank market).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The pooling and repackaging of cash income producing financial assets into securities that can then be sold to investors.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Supervisory Liquidity Review Process.

Resource.label: Supervisory Liquidity Review Process
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Supervisory Liquidity Review Process

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Operational Risk Requirement.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The supervisor for the country from which a banking entity is headquartered.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A Limited Licence Firm that does not hold client money or securities (and is not a UCITS investment firm). Base (minimum) capital requirements of EURO 50,000 apply.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The assessment and reporting of a firm's capital adequacy on an individual (unconsolidated) basis.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: An agreement between two counterparties where one stream of future interest payments is exchanged for another based on a notional principal amount. Interest rate swaps often exchange a fixed payment for a floating payment that is linked to an interest rate (e.g. LIBOR). Most swaps are traded over-the-counter.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A cycle of economic activity around a trend growth rate typically characterised by a trough, upswing, peak and downswing.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A bank, building society or investment firm that is subject to the Capital Requirements Directive.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: High quality liquid assets. In the context of the Liquidity Coverage Ratio, these are assets that can be converted into cash at little or no loss of value in private markets, to meet liquidity needs for a 30 calendar day liquidity stress scenario.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Also called Ancillary capital. This short-term subordinated debt was used under Basel II to support market risk from trading activities. This type of capital is abolished under Basel III.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Assets/liabilities that have been committed but not yet transacted. In terms of credit risk, off balance sheet items are obligations to make loans or other payments in the future.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Too big to fail. Term used to denote a bank that would substantially damage the financial system and the rest of the economy should it fail. See also Systemically Important Financial Institution.

Resource.label: Systemically Important Financial Institution
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Systemically Important Financial Institution

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The ratio of an institution's own capital resources to its risk weighted assets.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The ratio of a bank's stock of unencumbered, high quality liquid assets to net cumulative cash outflows over a 30 calendar day period. To meet the Basel III definition, the ratio must be greater than 100% for a combined firm-specific (idiosyncratic) and market-wide shock scenario. Net cash outflows must be calculated according to the scenario parameters set by the regulator.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Minimum. On a sliding scale, the floor would be the minimum percentage or amount that would apply.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The part of the Basel II Accord that sets out the process by which a bank should review its overall capital adequacy and the processes under which the supervisors evaluate how well financial institutions are assessing their risks and take appropriate actions in response to the assessments.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Individual Liquidity Adequacy Assessment.

Resource.label: Individual Liquidity Adequacy Assessment
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Individual Liquidity Adequacy Assessment

Resource.label: ILAA
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Supervisory Liquidity Review Process

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Tier 2 capital is supplementary bank capital that includes items such as undisclosed reserves, general loss reserves, hybrid debt/equity capital and subordinated debt of a financial institution.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Fund made available for start up firms and or small businesses with exceptional growth potential.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The procedures and measures taken by the authorities to resolve the situation of an unviable bank i.e. a bank failing or likely to fail to satisfy threshold conditions.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Lending by one bank to another.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Financial Stability Board.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Synonym for Capital Ratio.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Commonly used to mean the ratio of assets to the firm's capital base. Under the Basel III definition, the bank's capital is restricted to Tier 1 Capital; the 'exposure measure' goes beyond on-balance sheet assets to include securities funding transactions and derivative exposures together with off-balance sheet items (reduced to 10% where unconditionally cancellable).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Individual Liquidity Adequacy Standards.

Resource.label: Individual Liquidity Adequacy Standards
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Individual Liquidity Adequacy Standards

Resource.label: ILAS
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Individual Liquidity Systems Assessment

Resource.label: Advanced Internal Ratings Based Approach
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Advanced Internal Ratings Based Approach

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The most sophisticated of the three approaches available for the measurement of credit risk under Basel II, where banks can provide their own estimates of PD, LGD, EAD and Maturity. It involves the use of internal models based on internally generated parameters for the calculation of regulatory capital requirements.

Resource.label: Abbreviation
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Advanced Internal Ratings Based Approach\Attribute0

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A firm's own assessment of its capital requirements resulting from its ICAAP (Internal Capital Adequacy Assessment Process).

Resource.label: Internal Capital Adequacy Assessment Process
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Internal Capital Adequacy Assessment Process

Resource.label: Bank for International Settlements
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Bank for International Settlements

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Formed in 1930, it is the oldest of all the international financial organisations, coordinating the activities of national banking regulatory and supervisory bodies on a global level. The BIS governs several committees including the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision.

Resource.label: Basel Committee on Banking Supervision
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Basel Committee on Banking Supervision

Resource.label: Abbreviation
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Bank for International Settlements\Attribute0

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Areas where a supervisory authority sets higher standards than those required by the revised Accord and/or Capital Requirements Directive.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The other party that participates in a financial transaction.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Determination of the resilience of a business model by considering a variety of severe yet plausible scenarios that give rise to unexpected demands on capital and/or liquidity and could result in financial distress. Stress testing is an important tool in the evaluation of the potential impact of a specific set of adverse conditions on the firm's business.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: European Commission.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The amount of capital that must be assigned to meet a firm's regulatory obligations, such as to cover credit risk, market risk and operational risk.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Liquidity Metric Monitor.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The 1993 European Directive (93/6/EEC) expanding the Basel regime to Investment Firms as well as introducing regulatory capital requirements for market risk. (See also Capital Requirements Directive).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A bank or other financial industry entity.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A parameter reflecting the relative risk of a type of lending, counterparty (credit risk) or business activity (operational risk). These weightings are used in the calculation of regulatory capital requirements.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: In December 2010, the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision published its reforms to capital and liquidity rules to address the lessons of the financial crisis that began in 2007. Capital and liquidity standards are set out in two separate policy documents (BCBS188 & BSBS189), which together form the Basel III framework. Basel III strengthens the Basel II framework rather than replaces it. Whereas Basel II focused on the asset side of the balance sheet, Basel III mostly addresses the liabilities side i.e. capital and liquidity.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The European Commission embodies and upholds the general interests of the European Union. It is represented by 20 appointed Commissioners (including its President) and has the sole right of initiative on the proposal of legislation.

Resource.label: European Commission
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Recovery and Resolution Directive

Resource.label: European Commission
Resource.identity: Basel III Glossary\Committee of European Banking Supervisors

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Lending by a financial institution that is made to an incorporated company rather than to an individual.
